Legal_Issue: Whether the adjudicator correctly determined Widrig was an independent contractor rather than an employee
Evidence_Assessment: Widrig worked exclusively for Mamit, received tools and benefits, had no financial risk, and was integrated into Mamit’s operational structure
Decision_Outcome: Adjudicator initially found Widrig to be an independent contractor
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to establish employee status under the Canada Labour Code
Legal_Rule: Under s. 240(1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code, only employees with 12 months of continuous employment may file unjust dismissal complaints; determination of 'employee' hinges on subordination and control
Procedural_Issue: Correctness of adjudicator's classification of worker status
Grounds_for_Claim: Unjust dismissal due to misclassification as independent contractor
Outcome_on_Merits: Federal Court found Widrig was an employee, remitted case for redetermination
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Adjudicator's decision found unreasonable due to incorrect application of employee test
Key_Evidence_Considered: Exclusivity of work, provision of tools and benefits, lack of financial risk, integration into employer's business
Legal_Framework: Canada Labour Code – Part III (Unjust Dismissal)
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged adjudicator's finding that he was not an employee
Court_Result: Judicial review allowed; Widrig recognized as employee
Defendant_Response: Argued Widrig was an independent contractor based on initial contractual characterization
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, working relationship details, benefit provisions, tool usage
Outcome: Case remitted to a different adjudicator for further consideration
Remedy_Sought: Recognition as employee and hearing on unjust dismissal
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative tribunal process with judicial review by Federal Court
Legal_Provision_Cited: s. 240(1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of standing due to alleged contractor status
Applicable_Process: Unjust dismissal complaint under federal labour law
Outcome_of_Review: Successful judicial review; decision set aside
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction under Canada Labour Code
Governing_Rule: Employee status determined by degree of control and subordination
